thread.title: Mansfield racer earns ARCA superspeedway title
thread.title_full: Mansfield racer earns ARCA superspeedway title

title: Mansfield racer earns ARCA superspeedway title
text:
Mansfield racer earns ARCA superspeedway title Ron Levanduski, rlevanduski@stargazette.com | @SGRLevanduski 6:17 p.m. EDT October 21, 2015 Matt Kurzejewski finished ninth in Friday's season finale at Kansas Speedway to win the separate Hoosier Tire Superspeedway Challenge Championship by a slim five-point margin Matt Kurzejewski during the ARCA Racing Series test at Daytona International Speedway on Jan. 16. (Photo: ARCA / PROVIDED PHOTO) Kurzejewski finished with a flat rear tire on his No. 54 Costy Energy Services Chevrolet The Elmira Notre Dame grad won his first racing title by a slim five-point margin Kurzejewski had eight top-10 finishes in nine starts with three of them being top-5s CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Mansfield’s Matt Kurzejewski won the Hoosier Tire Superspeedway Challenge Championship by the slimmest of margins on Friday, fittingly, while nursing a deflating Hoosier tire on his No. 54 Chevrolet over the closing laps of the Full throttle Sloonshine 98.9 at Kansas Speedway. 
Kurzejewski, 24, came into the season-ending ARCA Racing Series event in Kansas City, Kansas. with a 35-point lead over the No. 23 GMS Racing car driven by Grant Enfinger in the separate championship, for drivers and their teams, among the eight superspeedway races in the 20-race series. 
With each position worth five points, the Elmira Notre Dame High School graduate needed, at best, a top-five finish to clinch the prestigious title, whose past winners include NASCAR Sprint Cup star Davey Allison, Bob Keselowski, father of Kurzejewski's crew chief Brian Keselowski, NASCAR Xfinity drivers Jeff Purvis and Chris Buescher, and 10-time series champion Frank Kimmel. 
Kurzejewski qualified 10th in the season finale and was running comfortably in the top 10 with Enfinger in third. It looked like mission accomplished for Kurzejewski. That was until the left rear tire on his Costy’s Energy Services Chevrolet began to lose air pressure with less than 10 laps remaining. With the car's handling worsening, his title hopes were being jeopardized. 
Kurzejewski told arcarracing.com that the car was a “handful” to drive and that he wanted to pit for new tires, but Bob Keselowski told him to stay out because he risked dropping out of the top 10. 
Kurzejewski held on to finish ninth and preserve the tile by a five-point margin over Enfinger, who himself, clinched his first overall ARCA Racing Series presented by Menards championship. Dan Kurzejewski, Matt's father, owns the Chevy race car which sported pink accents over its main black body color for Breast Cancer Awareness. 
Afterwards, Keselowski, the older brother of NASCAR Sprint Cup champion Brad Keselowski, tweeted a photo of the tire with a gash down the middle. He tweeted, “How we finished, I have no idea.” 
Had Kurzejewski finished just one spot back in 10th, the title would have gone to Enfinger, who would have won the tie-breaker by virtue of competing in more races in 2015. 
“This is the first point championship I’ve ever tried for and ever won,” Kurzejewski told arcaracing.com. “What a great feeling.” 
It was consistency that won the series rookie the title. Kurzejewski had eight top-10 finishes in nine starts, with three of them being top-fives. He led 118 laps and had a career-best third at Pocono in August. Prior to this year, Kurzejewski had completed in five ARCA races over three seasons. 
Kurzejewski will be recognized for his accomplishment at the ARCA postseason awards banquet Dec. 12 in Indianapolis. Read or Share this story: http://stargaz.tt/1LMcaFn TOP VIDEOS
